__data__.text:
- Born in Jerez de la Frontera, Spain in 1919
- Father, Alvaro Picardo de Celis, died when he was 10 years old
- Moved to Madrid and enrolled in Instituto de Bachillerato Cervantes
- Initially wanted to join the navy, but turned to law and then architecture
- Joined architect Luis Moya Blanco's studio during Spanish Civil War
- Entered Escuela Técnica Superior de Arquitectura de Madrid in 1945
- Talent in painting and drawing noticed by architects, began illustrating for magazines
- First professional mural painting at age 20 in Cine Fígaro
- Collaborated with architect Fernando Chueca Goitia on building preservation and restoration
- Signed "Manifiesto de la Alhambra" of 1952, seeking inspiration from Alhambra for Spanish modern architecture
- Noted interest in historic architecture preservation and restoration.

- Chueca and Picardo shared an interest in the unchanging elements of Spanish architecture.
- Picardo was a signatory of the "Manifiesto de la Alhambra" of 1952, which sought inspiration from the Alhambra for a distinctively Spanish form of modern architecture.
- In the 1950s, Picardo pursued personal architectural ambitions, entering competitions and designing unbuilt projects.
- He co-designed a six-storey apartment building near Madrid's Plaza de Las Ventas with his brother Carlos.
- In the early 1960s, Picardo built houses in the Andalusian style on the Costa del Sol and in Jerez, and modernist apartment blocks for Urbis in Madrid.
- He began his notable work on the state-owned luxury hotel network Paradores de Turismo de España in the 1960s and 1970s.
- Picardo was known for his skills as a draughtsman and muralist.
- His works were published in Arquitectura Popular Española by Leopoldo Torres Balbás and were highly regarded.
- In 1959, Picardo was commissioned to design a pack of playing cards for the Spanish fashion brand Loewe.

- José Luis Picardo was an "outstanding" muralist and architectural illustrator.
- He traveled around Spain with Leopoldo Torres Balbás, making detailed drawings of vernacular architectural elements for Balbás' books.
- Picardo's published architectural drawings were highly regarded and described as "magnificent" by leading Spanish restoration architect Luis Menéndez-Pidal y Álvarez.
- In 1959, Picardo was commissioned to design a pack of baraja de naipes (playing cards) for Spanish fashion brand Loewe, featuring personalized characters such as Emperor Charlemagne, Goliath, Julius Caesar, and Alexander the Great.
- Around 1960, Picardo also designed a set of wooden chess pieces with intricate, tall, slender, conical shapes and delicate indications of the pieces' types.
- In the early 1960s, Picardo was rewarded by the Dirección General de Arquitectura (DGA) with the publication of a book, Dibujos de José Luis Picardo, featuring more than 60 of his drawings, illustrations, and humorous cartoons.
- From the early 1960s to 1985, Picardo dedicated much of his professional life to Paradores de Turismo de España, a state-run hotel chain.
- Picardo worked on a series of restorations of old, monumental buildings and new establishments in a style that faithfully copied their original designs.
- His hybrid conversions maintained and often embellished the monuments' ancient appearance while providing luxurious modern hotel arrangements.
- Picardo carried out eleven major reconstructions of historical buildings and/or erected sympathetic and imitative new constructions for Paradores.
- His work for Paradores de Turismo is highly regarded by other professionals and hotel guests who appreciate the historical imagery and romance of his work.

- Architect Francisco Javier Sáenz de Oiza Picardo worked on 11 major historical building reconstructions and new constructions for Paradores de Turismo in Spain from the early 1960s to the 1980s.
 
- His first project was the Parador de Guadalupe in 1963, where he converted two ancient buildings, Hospital de San Juan Bautista and Colegio de Infantes, into a Parador.

- The buildings were in a ruinous state, and Picardo's task was to save the basic structures, including an "outstanding" staircase, and return them to their original Mudéjar style.

- He used ancient Mudéjar construction techniques based on lime, clay, and wood for the reconstruction.

- The main hospitality section of the Parador was set within the Colegio de Infantes, and the Hospital de San Juan Bautista was remodeled for the hotel's kitchens, service areas, laundry, staff residences, and car parking.

- Picardo also designed a large first-floor breakfast room on the street side of the hospital building.

- Most of the furniture and internal decoration was designed by Picardo, and he made much use of decorative wall tiles produced by the ceramicist Juan Manuel Arroyo Ruiz de Luna.

- Restoration at Guadalupe started in November 1963 and the hotel, with twenty double rooms, opened on 11 December 1965.

- In 1981, Picardo was invited back to Guadalupe to add a new wing of guest rooms, which increased the number of guest rooms to 41.

- At the same time as preparing his restoration at Guadalupe, Picardo was commissioned by the Ministry to design and build a Parador at the Castillo de Santa Catalina (Castle of Santa Catalina) in Jaén in Andalucía.

- Parador de Jaén: Castillo de Santa Catalina is a restoration project by Picardo, commissioned by the Ministry in the early 1960s.
- The castle, built in the mid-13th century, was originally a Moorish fortress and had been abandoned by the time Picardo started the project.
- Picardo's design is a simple hostería, built on the location of the old barracks and stables, with large windows for visitors to enjoy the views.
- The first phase of the building, completed in 1965, included:
  - 7 double guest rooms with fireplaces and wooden balconies
  - A mezzanine floor with a cafetería, bar, and outside terrace
  - Reception area, lounge, restaurant, service areas, and 4 single rooms for drivers on the ground floor
- The basic structure is 20th-century concrete, steel, block, and cement, but Picardo hid it with stone, brick, timber, and iron to suggest age.
- In 1969, Picardo added service rooms and converted the old service area into 12 more guest rooms.
- Excessive rain in the late 1960s and early 1970s caused landslips, requiring Picardo to strengthen the building.
- In 1973, Picardo built a further extension with 24 guest rooms, bringing the total to 43, and elevating the building to the title of Parador.
- Picardo designed the building's interior, producing furniture, wall-hangings, shutters, carpets, light fittings, door furniture, floor and wall tile patterns, and coats of arms from demolished buildings for both the interior and exterior of the Parador.

- 24 guest rooms added by Picardo's extension to building, now a Parador, with total of 43 rooms
- Extension caused long corridors and distances between bedrooms and public areas due to land layout and height limitations
- Picardo designed interior, producing medieval-style furniture, wall-hangings, shutters, carpets, light fittings, door furniture, floor and wall tile patterns, and coats of arms from demolished buildings for interior and exterior
- Hand-painted written ceramic tiles by Juan Manuel Arroyo used for decoration and crediting surveyor and stoneworker
- Picardo's architectural style at Jaén and Guadalupe Paradores, with artesonado ceilings, vaults, arches, wood, clay, and stone, was favored by clients and guests and used in most further work
- Parador at Arcos de la Frontera in Cádiz, Andalucía, located in old town with preserved façades, demolished old municipal slaughterhouse and other buildings, and 7 reused 2.35 meter columns
- 15 centimeter crack at cliff's top from 1755 Lisbon earthquake resolved by constructing a patio on an independent structure
- Picardo's design is a copy of a typical Andalucían residence with entrance hallway, typical patio, small secondary patios, dining and sitting rooms with widespread views, and Andalucían architectural features
- Picardo designed interior furniture, fittings, lighting, decoration, and ceramic tiles for explanatory texts
- 18 guest rooms planned, but initially only 9 built, some in building facing plaza and some fronting cliff-edge view with open wooden galleries.

* Architect, Picardo, designed the Parador in Arcos de la Frontera, which opened in 1966 with 9 guest rooms and expanded in 1974 to include 18 rooms.
* Picardo also designed Hostería de Pedraza, named "Pintor Zuloaga," in 1967, which was a restaurant and bar without guest rooms.
* In 1969, Picardo proposed expanding Hostería de Pedraza to include 16 guest rooms, but the project was not possible due to difficulties in purchasing neighboring property.
* The Hostería closed in 1992 due to economic pressures on the Parador chain.
* Picardo began converting the Palacio de los Comendadores at Alcañiz in Aragon into a Parador in 1966, which was completed with only 12 guest rooms due to limited space.
* The castle, Castillo de los Calatravos, was built in 1179 and declared a National Monument in 1925, but had fallen into disrepair before the conversion.
* Picardo's design for the public areas of the Alcañiz Parador included converting two large ground floor interiors with pointed barrel-vaulted ceilings on each side of the entrance.

- The castle in Alcañiz, Spain, was turned into a Parador, a type of Spanish luxury hotel, in 1968.
- The castle had been a National Monument since 1925 and was in disrepair before the renovation.
- The designer, Picardo, was limited by the space in the castle and could only create 12 guest rooms.
- The ground floor of the Parador has a medieval design, while the upper floors have a more palatial decor.
- Picardo designed much of the joinery, furniture, and light fittings, using the emblem of the Order of Calatrava as a decorative motif.
- He also incorporated his characteristic ceramic murals, produced by Juan Manuel Arroyo, into the public parts of the building.
- In 1972, Picardo reported on the feasibility of increasing the number of rooms, and in 1998, his original 1975 designs were resurrected and altered to expand the Parador to 38 guest rooms.
- Picardo was also commissioned to work on the Palacio del Comendador de Alcúescar in Cáceres, Spain, in 1966.
- The palace, originally built in 1488, had been modified over the centuries and included Gothic, Renaissance, and Baroque elements.
- Picardo worked on a jumble of old buildings, mostly stables and coach houses, attached to the main palace building.
- He demolished most of the service buildings, keeping a square structure with substantial stone walls and four brick, groined vaults.
- Picardo used architectural elements from the demolished buildings to erect three further floors above the lower-ground floor, making the lower ground floor the bar and cafetería with a doorway from the street as the main entrance to the Hostería.

- The Ministry proposed to convert part of the palace into a Hostería, with Picardo leading the project.
- Picardo decided to demolish most of the service buildings, keeping a square structure with substantial stone walls and four brick, groined vaults.
- He converted the lower ground floor into a bar and cafetería, and built three more floors above it, reusing architectural elements from the demolished buildings.
- A sgraffito image of the cross of the Orden de Santiago was installed above the main doorway.
- A one-storey building was erected at the rear, with ashlar and solid brick walls and pantiles on the roofs.
- Large areas were excavated beneath the buildings for service areas.
- Picardo designed a stone and iron enclosure and entrance gateway from the street to the patio garden.
- Internally, Picardo used pastiche medievalisms, heavy timber, dark coffered ceiling, classic Castilian designs for windows, doors, furniture, and light fittings, and terracotta tiles for the floors.
- The Hostería de Cáceres opened on 18 May 1971.
- Picardo also worked on the complete re-roofing of the palace and an extension to the original dining room area.
- The Hostería was closed in June 1984 and the rest of the palace was converted into a full Parador, opening on 10 October 1989.
- In 1966, Picardo was commissioned to inspect three ancient sites near Sevilla, including the Alcázar del Rey Don Pedro in Carmona.
- The castle was probably Muslim in origin and Pedro I restored it in the 14th century in Mudéjar style.
- The castle was abandoned after being severely damaged in earthquakes and only seven towers remained.
- Picardo chose the southeast of the castle area, the Plaza de Armas, to build the Parador.

- The castle in Carmona, Spain, has Muslim origins and was restored by Pedro I in the 14th century into a lavish palace in Mudéjar style.
- The castle was used by the Catholic Monarchs of Spain during their final battles with the Moors in Granada but was abandoned after being severely damaged in earthquakes in 1504 and 1755.
- Seven towers remained, but most of the connecting walls of the fortress were in ruins.
- In 1968, architect Picardo began preparatory work to build a Parador (a state-owned luxury hotel) in the southeast of the castle area, known as the Plaza de Armas.
- The chosen location had previously been revealed to have a deep crack and subsidence due to the 1504 earthquake, but Picardo and his engineers were unaware of this.
- In 1969, a survey revealed the potential instability of the ground, and the Public Works Geological Service was brought in to locate an underground fault.
- Despite the fault, the geologists considered the ground to be stable with protective measures, and cement was injected to fill cavities and a reinforced concrete slab was constructed.
- Picardo designed a typical Hispanic-Arabic layout with two central patios, one for the public area and one for the service department, replicating the original fortress layout.
- The building would have four floors on the south and east walls, which would slope outwards, allowing for the installation of rooms within them.
- The original plan was for 23 double guest rooms and 10 singles, but a pre-completion expansion brought the total guest capacity to 102.
- Most of the rooms would be on the southern façade, with some below the Parador's access level and others in what would appear to be the third and fourth floors.
- The main structure of the building would be formed of concrete, clad with ashlar and brickwork, and enhanced by buttresses.
- The roof would be formed of clay pantiles, topped with decorative chimneys, and internally, limestone columns and ceramic tiling would be used.
- Picardo had control of the interior decoration, achieving a Hispanic-Arabic ambience of a palatial Mudéjar

- The Carmona Parador, designed by Picardo, was inaugurated in 1976 with a clay pantile roof, limestone columns, ceramic tiling, and marble/terracotta floors, creating a Hispanic-Arabic ambience.
- In 1976, a large crack was detected parallel to the south façade, leading to an expansion joint and underpinning of the south wall in 1980 and 1987.
- Despite improvements, movement was detected in 1996, and further cracks appeared in 2013, posing a risk in case of a rise in the water table or an earthquake.
- In 1982-1983, minor improvements and modernizations were carried out under Jesús Valverde Viñas, and an expansion with additional guest rooms and a convention pavilion was added in 1987 by Carlos Fernández-Cuenca Gómez.
- In 1964, Picardo investigated old buildings for conversion into a Parador in the Province of Guadalajara, considering the ruined Castillo de Sigüenza the best proposition.
- The Castillo de Sigüenza, a palace-fortress with Iberian, Roman, Visigothic, and Moorish origins, was enlarged and modified between the 14th and 18th centuries, suffering damage during the French invasion, Carlist Wars, and Spanish Civil War.
- Picardo started analyzing the castle's condition in October 1969, finding it in a pitiful state.

- The Castillo de los Obispos de Sigüenza, a palace-fortress with Iberian, Roman, Visigothic, and Moorish origins, was acquired by the Ministry in the same year it stood prominently above the town and cathedral of Sigüenza.
- The castle had been enlarged and modified between the 14th and 18th centuries, but it declined and deteriorated due to various invasions and wars, leaving it in ruins for over three decades.
- In 1969, Picardo analyzed the castle's condition, finding it in a pitiful state. He proposed a total medieval remodel, obliterating almost all of its later history.
- The reconstruction of the entire castle began in 1972, with the goal of creating a purely medieval fortress, hiding or disguising later additions.
- Picardo raised most outer walls by at least one more storey, causing flat roofs and allowing for hotel accommodation. The towers were also further raised, including the twin towers of the fortified gateway.
- All large windows, balconies, and wide openings were removed, reducing the size of remaining windows and rebuilding destroyed parts with the remaining stone detritus.
- Plaster and rendering were removed to reveal the original bare stone, and later buildings attached to the exterior were demolished.
- The central courtyard was cleared of all post-medieval accretions, with 40,000 tons of debris removed.
- In the reconstruction of the interior, Picardo used modern elements like steel, reinforced concrete, blockwork, and cement, hiding them behind a historical veneer of walls, beams, arches, and cladding made of stone, brick, timber, and iron.
- Daylight had to reach the interior by making many window openings in the courtyard walls.
- The main reception area was installed on the north wall of the courtyard, approached from the outside by the barbican towers, with bedrooms and balconied terraces above, built in Picardo's signature timber style.

- 40,000 tons of debris removed from castle courtyard
- Picardo used modern materials (steel, reinforced concrete, blockwork, cement) for castle's basic structure, but hid them behind historical facade of stone, brick, timber, and iron
- Reduced exterior window size necessitated many window openings in courtyard walls for daylight
- Main reception area and portico with pillars and intermediate glass installed on north wall of courtyard
- Bedrooms with balconied terraces built in signature timber style above reception area
- Historical sgraffito decoration replicated on northern walls of courtyard
- Bishops' throne room on ground floor converted into main guest lounge with timber-beamed ceiling and two large fireplaces
- Dining room on east side of ground floor with large windows overlooking wooded ravine
- Powerful stone vaulting used to hide steel supporting structure of floor above in dining room
- Vaulted bar and café installed on courtyard side of dining room
- Wide wooden staircases on eastern side leading to first and second floor bedrooms
- Original chapel preserved
- Smaller monastic courtyard built at southern end of castle with guest rooms arranged around it
- 65 meters long banqueting hall with stone vaulting installed on inner face of west wall
- Large service areas installed below banqueting hall
- Picardo provided interior decor with special attention to medieval themes
- 38 guest rooms and one suite on first floor, 42 rooms and one suite on second floor, providing space for 162 guests
- Mural of 45 tiles recounting castle's history and restoration work placed on main entrance hall wall
- Building work completed in 1976, Parador opened to public on 20 July 1976, and was inaugurated by King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofía in April 1978
- Remodelling and modernisation of Parador took place in 1990 under direction of architect Carlos Fernández-Cuenca Gómez, who followed Picardo's style
- Parador has maintained its original character as established by Picardo.

- Don José Luis Picardo was an architect who worked on several Parador projects in Spain in the 1960s and 1970s.
- He was responsible for the restoration and medieval character preservation of the exterior of the Parador in Sigüenza, which was completed in 1976 and inaugurated by King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofía in 1978.
- Picardo's last major project for the Paradores was the remodeling and modernization of the Parador in Sigüenza in 1990.
- He also investigated and reported on other old buildings for possible conversion into Paradores, including:
  - The castle in Puebla de Alcocer (plans not realized)
  - The 11th century remains of the castle in Monzón (project deemed unviable)
  - The old palace at Olite in Navarra (completed by other architects)
  - The Castillo de la Zuda at Tortosa in Cataluña (completed by other architects)
  - The castle at Cardona in Cataluña (completed by other architects)
- Picardo also surveyed several other buildings which were not ultimately converted into Paradores, including:
  - The Castillo de San Antón at A Coruña
  - The Posada del Cordón at Atienza
  - The Palacio del Deán and the Palacio del Dr Trujillo at Plasencia
  - The Castillo de Segunto near Valencia
  - The castle at Molina de Aragón
  - The Castillo de Valderrobres in Teruel
  - The castle at Trujillo
  - The cave houses of Mesón Gitano
  - The Alcazaba of Almería
  - The castle-fortress at Aracena
- He developed improvements for an existing Parador, the castle at Ciudad Rodrigo in 1975.
- Picardo's rehabilitation projects were typically planned on the basis of his own historical and architectural research, without archeological research before or during the work.

- In 1975, Picardo developed improvements for the Parador at Ciudad Rodrigo, a castle in Salamanca, Spain.
- His rehabilitation projects in the 1960s-1970s, like at Sigüenza, were based on his own research, without archaeological investigation.
- This lack of investigation is now seen as controversial by historians and archaeologists.
- Picardo's work has been described as creating "convincing set design" for a historical era, often the medieval period.
- His extensions, like the one at Jaén, are described as "false history" as they mimic the original structures.
- Picardo defended his approach, stating that if the reconstructions are Art, they are justified.
- He used modern techniques concealed with traditional materials to make buildings look old.
- Despite current views, Picardo's Paradores, particularly those at Jaén, Carmona, and Sigüenza, remain popular.
- Picardo also carried out restoration works on:
  - Catedral de Cádiz
  - Real Monasterio de Santa María de Guadalupe
  - Catedral de Santa María de Sigüenza
  - Ermita del Humilladero
  - Antiguo Palacio del Marqués de Montana
  - Palacio Domecq
  - Palacio de Gamazo
  - Castillo de San Felipe
  - Archivo Histórico Provincial de Salamanca.

- Picardo was a renowned architect known for his work on classical styles.
- He restored several buildings, including Catedral de Cádiz, Real Monasterio de Santa María de Guadalupe, Catedral de Santa María de Sigüenza, Ermita del Humilladero, Antiguo Palacio del Marqués de Montana, Palacio de Gamazo, Castillo de San Felipe, and Archivo Histórico Provincial de Salamanca.
- In 1970, Picardo competed with other architects for the contract to design a new headquarters building for Fundación Juan March in Madrid.
- He won the competition and designed a building with seven floors above ground and four below ground, with a total area of 4,400 square meters.
- The building was designed with continuous horizontal banding without breaks around the corners, with ribbon windows and white Carrara marble cladding.
- The interior of the building features assembly halls, auditoria, exhibition and gallery spaces, libraries, offices, Council rooms, conveniences, and car parking below ground.
- The predominant materials used inside the building are white marble, bronze, and walnut, with much carpeting and a wide staircase with fabric walls.
- The building houses two performance spaces, one with 300 seats and the other with 100, as well as a large hall connecting the two spaces.
- Picardo integrated pictorial and sculptural works into the architecture, including sculptures by Eduardo Chillida and Pablo Serrano and a mural by Joaquín Vaquero Turcios.
- The large bronze double doors in the south façade leading to the garden were designed by Picardo.
- The garden, designed by Picardo, covers 1,700 square meters and was intended to be a significant part of the project.
- The building was inaugurated in January 1975 and received acclaim for its design and architecture.

- Eduardo Chillida, Pablo Serrano, and Joaquín Vaquero Turcios sculptures, as well as a mural, were featured in a building designed by Juan Picardo in Madrid.
- The building, inaugurated in 1975, includes large bronze double doors and a 1,700 square meter garden, both designed by Picardo.
- Picardo's building in Madrid is considered one of the best in recent Madrid history.
- In 1978, Picardo was commissioned to design a riding arena for the Real Escuela Andaluza del Arte Equestre in Jerez de la Frontera, Spain.
- The arena, called Sal de Equitación, was designed in a neo-Renaissance style, incorporating Andalusian colors and architecture.
- The Sal de Equitación has a seating capacity of 1,600 and includes stable facilities for 60 horses.
- The interior features a rectangular display area with seating on six tiers, and the exterior color scheme is repeated inside.
- The Sal de Equitación was opened for performances in 1980.
- In 1981, Pablo Picasso's Guernica was brought to Spain and permanently hung in the Museo Nacional del Prado.
- Picardo and José García María de Paredes designed a secure display for Guernica using armored glass and a steel polyhedron case.
- The armored glass and steel case was built to protect the painting from potential threats while providing optimal viewing conditions.

- "Guernica" painting: 7.76m long, 3.49m high
- Largest available armoured glass: 7.50m long, 2.45m high
- Solution: armoured glass and steel polyhedron case, bevels meet floor, walls, ceiling
- Painting set at 10 degrees to the vertical, lit with no shadows, reflections or distortions
- Displayed in a large high space (originally a ballroom)
- Over 1 million people saw the painting within a year of installation
- Display method received mixed reviews
- Picasso's daughter, Paloma Picasso, and artists Josep Renau and Josep Lluís Sert praised the display
- British art critic Douglas Cooper admired the lighting and display
- British art critic David Sylvester criticized the location of the painting in an annexe to the Prado
- In 1992, the painting was moved to a purpose-built gallery at the Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía
- Picardo gifted the academy his oil painting "Guardia civil en el puerto de Alazores" in 2000
- Picardo was elected Academician of the Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando in 1997
- Picardo won the Premio Antonio Camuñas de Arquitectura in 2001
- Picardo was praised for his knowledge of Spanish culture and his reinterpretation and valuation of historical heritage
- Picardo was an architect, artist, and professor
- Picardo was passionate about architecture and horses
- Picardo was elected to the Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando at the age of 78
- Picardo's portrait by Luis García-Ochoa Ibáñez is housed in the academy's collection
- Picardo's oil painting "Guardia civil en el puerto de Alazores" is housed in the academy's collection
- Picardo's sons donated his portrait to the academy in 2023.

* Painted in 1953, a portrait of Picardo at age 34
* Donated to the academy by his sons in 2023
* Won Premio Antonio Camuñas de Arquitectura in 2001
	+ Awarded every 2 years since 1985
	+ Recognizes Spanish architects who have made significant contributions to architectural renovation
	+ Picardo praised for his knowledge of culture and reinterpretation of historical heritage
* Married Trinidad de Ribera Talavera and had 5 children (3 boys, 2 girls)
* Described as a "package of energy, wit and imagination" with "twinkling" eyes by a US travel journalist in 1972
* Died on 27 July 2010 in Madrid.
